awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Search Assistance Using Search Trails
awd_abstract_narration:
Current search systems are effective in helping users complete simple search tasks, but provide less support for complex tasks. When users search for information, they create "search trails" based on their interactions with the search system. These trails have valuable information that could benefit a future searcher working on a similar task and may include the queries issued, results clicked, pages viewed, pages bookmarked, and annotations made by a previous searcher. Currently, many search engines use these activity traces to improve their search algorithms and results. However, current approaches are limited; they may lead to indirect benefits, but do not consider the full potential of search trails as a direct form of search assistance. This research will develop and evaluate systems that automatically display relevant search trails as a form of search assistance to users. Using search trails for search assistance has the potential to improve a broad range of systems, including web search engines used by millions, digital libraries, and enterprise and website-specific search engines that serve users with similar goals and needs. The outcomes of this project will expand the accessibility of search across a wide range of domains. The research project will produce data that will allow other researchers to develop and evaluate their own solutions and tools that will facilitate others to perform large-scale studies of search behavior. Insights gained from the studies will also be of interest to researchers in other fields such as psychology and education. 

Prior research on search trails has suggested the usefulness of search trails, but has not answered key research challenges required to design and implement them. The system needs to predict when to display search trails to a user, which trails to display, and how to display them in a way that supports the user's goal. These challenges will be addressed in three phases. Phase 1 will determine which factors of the user, task, and system influence whether a searcher wants help, for what purpose, and whether they are able to gain useful information. These results will have implications for the design of assistance systems across a variety of domains. Phase 2 will develop models for predicting when to show trails to a user based on user and task features, as well as behavioral measures that indicate whether a searcher is having difficulty. The insights gained will help the development of search engines that are more user and task-aware. Finally, Phase 3 will develop models for predicting which trails to show for the current search session. Being able to match search sessions based on the user's higher-level goal has direct implications to other information retrieval tasks such as document ranking, query suggestion, and aggregated search. We will use learning-to-rank algorithms to combine features that measure the similarity between the current search session and the candidate trail, and the information content in the trail.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to investigate search interfaces and tools to support searchers with specific types of tasks. This project focused on four main areas of research.

 

First, in a crowdsourced study, we investigated the usefulness of search trails to support searchers with tasks of varying scope.  A search trail is an interactive visualization of how another searcher approached the same task or a related task.  A search trail typically includes the queries issued and clicks/bookmarks made by the previous searcher.  The study involved two manipulations.  First, we manipulated the tasks assigned to participants.  Tasks varied from highly open-ended (broadly scoped) to highly constrained (narrowly scoped).  Second, we manipulated the search trails given to participants.  Some trails originated from searchers who completed the most open-ended task version and other trails originated from searchers who completed the most narrowly scoped task version.  Our results found that participants had a better experience when they were provided with trails that matched the scope of their task.  Additionally, participants were better able to address narrowly focused tasks with broadly focused trails than vice-versa, suggesting that broadly focused trails are more useful when the scope of a searcher’s task is unknown.

 

Second, in a lab study, we investigated the effects of task complexity on the types of information needed by searchers.  To manipulate task complexity, we leveraged the cognitive process dimension from Anderson and Krathwohl’s (A&K’s) taxonomy of learning.  Participants were given access to a search assistance tool with information curated by previous searchers who completed the same task.  The tool provided access to four different types of information: facts, concepts, opinions, and insights.  Our results found that complex tasks required different types of information and more information that is subjective in nature (e.g., more insights versus facts).  Additionally, task complexity influenced the motivations for why participants engaged with the tool---to confirm information during simple tasks and to understand the task requirements during complex tasks.

 

Third, several studies focused on a research area known as “search-as-learning”.  Broadly speaking, “search-as-learning” research is interested in: (1) understanding factors that influence learning during search and (2) understanding how learning objectives influence the needs and experiences of searchers.  In one study, we investigated how searchers are influenced by the type of learning objective they are pursuing.  To manipulate learning objectives, we again leveraged A&K’s taxonomy.  However, this was the first study to consider both dimensions of the taxonomy: the cognitive process and the knowledge type dimension.  Interestingly, the knowledge type dimension had a stronger impact on participants’ perceptions and behaviors.  Specifically, conceptual objectives were perceived to be more difficult and required more search activity than factual and procedural objectives.  In another effort, we analyzed the “pathways” (i.e., sequences of subgoals) followed by searchers toward a specific learning objective.  Our results found interesting regularities in the types of pathways followed by participants.  For example, procedural objectives had pathways with more creative processes (e.g., procedure modifications).  In another study, we investigated the effects of goal-setting on learning during search.  To this end, we developed a tool to encourage and support searchers in setting goals and taking notes with respect to goals.  Participants who were given access to the tool (and set goals with good characteristics) achieved better learning outcomes.  Finally, we published an extensive review of different types of learning assessment methods used in “search-as-learning” research.  As part of this review, we advocated that future research should consider two dimensions of learning that have been ignored: (1) retention and  (2) transfer of learning.

 

Finally, one of our studies investigated different ways to presenting search results in a virtual reality environment.  The study investigated three display conditions: (1) a ranked list, (2) a (4 x 5) grid, and (3) a (2 x 10) arc spanning 220 degrees.  Participants were asked to find a target search result among those displayed or determine that the target was absent.  In the arc condition, participants completed tasks quicker when the target was absent but had more negative perceptions of their experience.  These results suggest that layouts that require more head movement may provide objective benefits but also have drawbacks in terms of perceptions.

 

In terms of broader impacts, this project made four important contributions.  First, we have evaluated the benefits of different tools to support searchers with complex search tasks.  Specifically, we have investigated tools that allow knowledge sharing and re-use.  Second, we have explored how people decompose learning-oriented tasks and have proposed tools to support these processes.  Third, we have published an extensive review of learning assessment methods that can be used in “search-as-learning” research.  This review provides tips for choosing the right learning assessment method based on research goals and study design.  Finally, we have explored different ways of displaying search results in a virtual reality environment.
